36c984ee-5274-4e94-bd49-71f749ae44fa	there are all sorts of ways to give buy and sell instructions to a broker -- and just as many ways to get burned if you don't know what you're doing
806a8025-9ebb-4812-b876-ecc59bcbdef1	with a market order, an investor tells a broker to buy or sell "at the market
f1551372-b5c2-47cb-b311-95d23c00209b	it's like saying, "get me in now" or "get me out now
b9e705ce-b998-4d27-8ff7-7a250ec64689	suppose an investor wants to sell a stock, but not for less than $55
3f28942d-64b5-4477-b130-5dc4c172e0f1	a limit order to sell could be entered at that price
bb3bebd7-aa93-4438-9873-679d96b13f48	stop orders tell a floor broker to buy or sell an investment once the price reaches a certain level
feabe6a5-033d-4728-98fd-ca4751cc8656	once the price reaches that level, a stop order turns into a market order, and the order is filled at whatever price the broker can get
31f49ddd-744d-4ff0-a83f-e61ff51a8e6c	unlike stop orders stop-limit orders demand that the trades be made only at the specified price
370b0e3c-0336-4bf5-a643-e5c640390618	if it can't be made at that price, it doesn't get filled
2a5176e0-b1c0-42dc-8997-7f218e0c34d9	he uses fill-or-kill orders almost exclusively when trading options
d0dede4c-cae8-4802-9db6-8099f9bbae83	i like to use them to feel out the market
35231e9a-6788-4717-af92-97952759a34d	this is really two orders in one, generally for the same security or commodity, instructing floor brokers to fill whichever order they can first and then cancel the other order
ea9501ba-2c92-4e3f-9e76-a9fc4f8313f0	in a fast-moving market, it prevents an investor from getting stuck with having made two trades on the same security
f126161f-c76a-4d5d-9793-da3e4bb5f000	on oct. 19, 1987, some investors learned the consequences of entering "good-til-canceled limit orders" and then forgetting about them
da8b66ed-ced6-4a91-9b8d-0c6291ea5e52	they found they had bought stock from limit orders that they might have entered weeks or months earlier and had forgotten to cancel
fc8cff66-3133-47f0-8491-fc5af2dbc8a3	it is always the responsibility of investors to keep track of the orders they have placed

a2e190fe-7935-4423-b4be-77ad1a25b8ee	litigation consulting is highly manipulative

0ada6244-414a-4abe-aa99-2b718a6d08c8	it's gotten to the point where if the case is large enough, it's almost malpractice not to use them
b4538220-e23f-4abf-9f4c-1cb85fd29de7	sophisticated trial consulting grew, ironically, from the radical political movements of the 1960s and 1970s before finding its more lucrative calling in big commercial cases
2b97982f-9af2-40c9-b6b6-f03ce2250c89	the harrisburg 7 trial in 1972, in which daniel berrigan and others were charged with plotting anti-war-related violence, was a landmark
a7620421-d258-4ecf-8af4-3a9051d591ba	in that case, a group of left-leaning sociologists interviewed 252 registered voters around harrisburg
1d3a5ad3-3c8a-403f-8f56-61fd742673c1	the researchers discovered that episcopalians, presbyterians, methodists and fundamantalist protestants were nearly always against the defendants
752a95db-8076-4b65-bd6b-6c833fb92053	ultimately, that carefully picked jury deadlocked with a 10-2 vote to acquit, and the prosecution decided not to retry the case
98388fd8-1965-4d75-aaa3-eb548903efcc	litigation consulting had arrived

a9d33d27-68d5-4732-a33e-92053d36cbda	so here's a rundown of the most common types of market orders permitted by the stock and commodity exchanges
bd5e463c-3b37-428f-9604-93a65cf37b0e	two things to keep in mind
4f61ea63-5b91-4c7a-922c-553197a07f85	two things to keep in mind
d335e220-87ed-4388-805c-03bfdf7b2823	not all exchanges accept every type of order
56c8fada-bd91-4c3d-bb58-52a22dea5c34	for example, if wheat is being offered at $4.065 and bid at $4.060, a market order to buy would be filled at the higher price and a market order to sell at the lower price
118c479d-ccd0-443e-b8aa-463a1c48af80	that some floor brokers at the two largest chicago commodity exchanges used market orders to fill customers' orders at unfavorable prices by arranging trades with fellow brokers
75a0f8ad-23e6-418a-ba75-f6a74d14bbf1	investors do this by specifying a minimum price at which the investment may be sold or the maximum price that may be paid for it
4357f54f-3b27-476a-a229-eb841b2af220	suppose an investor wants to sell a stock, but not for less than $55
d2cefe98-b170-4d95-bf9f-bd51da691c12	once the price reaches that level, a stop order turns into a market order, and the order is filled at whatever price the broker can get
23d9467b-b1ac-4ba4-aae3-dfc3886e4c40	stop orders are sometimes called "stop-loss" orders because they are frequently used to protect profits or limit losses
a8080f7a-31e2-4932-9b8b-d3d12ca50a43	while stop orders sound similar to limit orders, there is a difference
941b04cd-bdca-4d52-8d00-3d0222cca2c2	sell stops must be entered at a price below the current market price and buy stops above.
69a746c0-c9e0-4b5d-b41c-65621c1fe660	the crash in october 1987 and last friday's sell-off painfully taught some investors exactly what stop orders will and won't do
bf5d2749-4362-4938-b99b-3b9583805033	an investor who may have placed a stop-loss order at $90 under a stock that was trading at $100 a share on the friday before the crash was stunned to discover that the order was filled at $75 when the stock opened at that price on monday
02ace4d5-3ca1-4934-9163-cb717610a74b	the fill-or-kill order is one of several associated with the timing of trades
74a32660-f223-4468-a5f7-f3e95da53daf	it instructs a broker to buy or sell an investment at the specified price or better
a4cdf3cf-e8cd-47a1-bcba-ac3295058093	i like to use them to feel out the market
6c69f8d6-e76d-4e55-98f8-3bb8019a521e	if they don't fill it immediately, then i can start over at a new price or try again with the same price
690e8749-1b5e-4962-8ff7-c71283572160	this is another timing order
21be8a9a-7e81-4ab5-80c1-5e948160a36e	it is a market order that allows floor brokers to take more time to buy or sell an investment, if they think they can get a better price by waiting
df5b75b5-2a6a-489d-b090-199cb0265194	this type of order couples many of the orders described above with instructions that the order must be carried out at or by a certain time
067f133e-e11e-468f-a4cf-8eac76e32174	on the close" can be added to many types of orders
6d0ea324-101c-4ae9-8f8a-46e06cd4d9f6	stop-close-only orders" are stop orders that only become active during the closing minutes of trading
6e2c3a1f-6156-42e4-a830-2cb3fb0bcfd2	day orders" expire at the end of the day on which they are entered, "good-till-canceled orders" have no expiration date

5f723f3c-264c-4ccd-9627-1b8967d3155c	call it the uninformed trudging after the incomprehensible
d5d54fbe-fcc9-47af-9883-69f2e1504aef	over the past decade or two the insurance industry has spawned an incredible number of products, variations on products, and variations on the variations
3145736d-81c6-4108-aeaa-49bb26495f6c	besides term life and whole life (the old standbys), we now have universal life, universal variable life, flexible adjustable universal life, policies with persistency bonuses, policies festooned with exotic riders, living benefit policies, and on and on
be203c8d-525d-4874-8ad8-7bef8d26e51a	first, generalize
935f757f-62f1-4667-80ca-addfc6822d8a	shorn of all their riders, special provisions, and other bells and whistles, insurance policies can still be grouped under two broad categories: so-called pure insurance, which amasses no cash value in the policy and pays off only upon death, and permanent insurance, which provides not only a death benefit but also a cash value in the policy that can be used in various ways while the insured is still alive
464de06e-632d-470f-b3ea-1f10fdb52546	if all you want is death-benefit coverage, pure insurance -- a term policy -- gives you maximum bang for your buck, within limits
c344dff3-c0ca-48b7-b22c-e3dedd2ee32d	it's much cheaper than permanent insurance bought at the same age
8188ccb3-2ca7-4847-89f8-ac4f72e15dc4	but "term" means just that
a226bedd-b305-45aa-a037-e923ad9e38c1	the policy is written for a specific time period only and must be renewed when it expires
bb0f55fe-ff7a-41a2-a359-d11beaa5ca4d	if you flunk you may not be able to buy it
cce4ae12-0936-4d9a-9b21-12dac744c181	even if you're healthy and can renew, your premium will go up sharply because you're that much older
ddd1131a-d6ea-42b0-8670-d977e6fa66d7	second, the $5,760 i'd get back would be much diminished in purchasing power by 10 years of inflation
36a40c9b-6935-4bea-b76d-697ae2ec493f	amex, not i, would get the benefit of the investment income on my money
6443b6af-9d13-445c-8fa9-2b277a43b127	which goes to show that the first law applies in insurance as in anything else
a3c29b03-9415-4e4f-b448-7c5f0e8fa766	there is no free lunch, there is only marketing
3a5d2c62-d021-4bbe-ad11-e7ce9abdd5d2	and in most cases, a huge hunk of your premium in the initial year or two of the the policy is, in effect, paying the salesman's commission as well
2957bdd3-2c88-4a64-85d5-f8ed85e44354	investment returns on most policies are actually negative for several years, largely because of this
b1179e96-72d7-4865-83d3-7cdf0d8685a9	the simplest, most traditional form of permanent insurance is the straight whole life policy
2ff85466-b496-4ca2-8d72-cf058c4712a5	you pay a set premium for a set amount of coverage, the company invests that premium in a portfolio of its choosing, and your cash value and dividends grow over the years
4ef04218-6f38-4f3f-b637-c812d7be18e3	hugely popular, it is far more flexible than straight whole life
cef48d8d-605a-4f78-a2b5-ab8c1fde32b2	i can adjust the amount of insurance i want against the amount going into investment

7ce1b078-79e0-4be6-87e4-49d5fcdbea09	that, at least at the federal level, political "ticket splitting" has been on the rise over the past half century
c88c3382-e743-4525-9f83-7faa18417c47	in only one presidential election year prior to 1948 did more than 20% of the nation's congressional districts choose a different party's candidate for the white house than for the house of representatives.
430cc58c-6f14-464f-9136-2469c80464a2	as we know, voters tend to favor republicans more in races for president than in those for congress
290eb479-ede5-41bb-b330-2b56ef5c1ab0	in every presidential election over the past half century, except for the goldwater presidential candidacy, the gop has captured a greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for congress
4b2fd70c-bd3d-4ef7-ac7f-107713532fe4	if these assumptions hold, voters in races for congress face what in economic theory is called a prisoner's dilemma and have an incentive, at the margin, to lean democratic
9b352ffd-febc-4a8d-9bba-00a90955969d	if they put a republican into office, not only will they acquire less in terms of local benefits but their selected legislator will be relatively powerless to prevent other legislators from "bringing home the bacon" to their respective constituencies
c5fca737-c412-4e94-8622-d750a4276e4d	second, it explains why voters hold congress in disdain but generally love their own congressional representatives
7b012ad5-7307-48b8-bc02-e78a64699ac3	any individual legislator's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator wins for them but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency
23602cc5-3a93-4cd3-a4f1-a88187ea8481	the one exception to this recent trend was the defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman republicans brought into office in 1980 by the reagan revolution and running for re-election in 1982
465df127-8245-46fa-8b94-23893fbc4b2d	because these freshmen placed far more emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were more vulnerable to defeat
421f432a-b944-4b33-9d0c-d35615b20b13	fourth, the theory indicates why the republican party may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office
e4734d9a-131b-4e09-9a8a-63ab6d15ad78	potential candidates may be discouraged from running less by the congressional salary than by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a democratic opponent
66376d9b-7825-4dd2-9dee-6f8b2ebd80b4	fifth, the theory may provide at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the south
884c7fc6-5131-46b2-8094-e80c583c0c4a	to the extent that democratic legislators from the south have held a disproportionate share of power in congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into relatively more local benefits for their respective constituencies, voters in the south have had an especially strong incentive to keep such democrats in office
36645d61-393a-4912-b2e8-46fa937c016f	finally, the theory suggests why republicans generally have fared better in senate races than in campaigns for the house
3132cc2e-4714-44ae-b7f4-1eadc311d184	since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of congress, this is precisely the pattern one would expect if republicans are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their democratic counterparts
2cadb402-102c-4b16-b18b-c23129d7d374	this is indeed what the data indicate, particularly in the case of the house
da303d62-235b-4e95-b8a7-ab16be9a7ff4	the democratic house attendance rate has not exceeded the republican house attendance rate since 1959
ce934235-55b3-44ec-9cad-681230b9a968	moreover, ticket splitting appears to take the same peculiar pattern at the state government level as it does at the federal level
3ce4b71d-f960-4f4c-ac31-d107268e209a	state government is more typically split along republican-governor/democratic-legislature lines than the reverse

e336fde2-1015-4f54-9141-12647a763bca	institutional investors have poured $210 billion into stock and bond indexing as a cheap and easy form of investment management that promises to post average market returns
1c77bd5d-b284-4825-b791-f8f1c9c66f80	these big investors have flocked to indexing because relatively few "active" stock pickers have been able to consistently match the returns of the s&p 500 or other bellwethers, much less beat it
7f4a4636-e0f3-407a-91d7-cfef184773b0	but today, indexing is moving from a passive investment strategy to an increasingly active one
abf46674-e5be-4713-b245-cad2b6a569f1	because index-fund managers are no longer satisfied with merely being average, they have developed "enhanced" indexing strategies that are intended to outperform the market as much as three percentage points
c60b6b6b-8a5c-48d2-a271-73adf3991d6f	indexed portfolios can be built around thousands of stocks, or just a few dozen, rather than being restricted to the s&p 500 companies
0e4f806b-a20a-4405-b57b-ce105f7c8b09	they can ignore the s&p 500 stocks altogether and focus on particular types of stocks, such as smaller companies, those paying high dividends or companies in a particular industry, state or country

78168ad4-5efc-44cb-a48e-b593d6156d8f	the solution, at least for some investors, may be a hedging technique that's well known to players in the stock-options market
512c1a88-1aa8-4107-ad83-2ecc2c65e127	called a "married put," the technique is carried out by purchasing a stock and simultaneously buying a put option on that stock
c3a3fc5e-dfbf-4b03-a89a-183cf9096bd4	it's like "fire insurance
ef150bb2-a49d-4291-b516-ba13a9f8212a	because a put option gives its owner the right, but not the obligation, to sell a fixed number of shares of the stock at a stated price on or before the option's expiration date, the investor is protected against a sudden drop in the stock's price
06741c9e-b1c2-4087-91e7-32cce1b1068c	if the price of the stock declines, the put will increase in value
533eb590-8172-414d-a98c-afbd20545531	once the stock price is less than the exercise price, or "strike price," of the put, the gain will match the loss on the stock dollar for dollar

781b7ebd-e81d-4a59-b5e2-3c97827ee50d	perhaps most exciting, the device is thrusting open a window to the workings of the brain
34e192bb-65c6-4706-9386-91b77b5c0288	the probe, which is painless, non-invasive and apparently harmless, employs strong magnetic fields to induce small whirlwinds of electricity within the brain
02e0bf8b-3298-4a4d-800d-48166267490f	if positioned over the brain's motor-control area, the hand-held electromagnets generate nerve impulses that zip down motor nerves and activate muscles, making, say, a finger twitch
25d47308-c510-4c7c-a3eb-3f8271878dab	until now, we've had no objective way of measuring motor function
a507951b-5166-4ffc-bef9-d604a78de300	all we could do was tell a patient, `squeeze my fingers as hard as you can' or `raise your arm
05455654-4055-48b7-9db1-35fdfdcd1ee1	since then, at least two commercial versions have been put on the u.s. market, and an estimated 500 have been sold
9458afc9-879b-4419-b1b5-810b0cfe08cc	in august, a chicago conference on such devices attracted more than 100 researchers, who reported studies on everything from brain mapping to physical therapy
0a79d1f0-06a8-4db5-a950-0d2468e7b96f	the main sensation, besides feeling like a puppet jerked with invisible strings, is "like a rap on the head
0020ed9d-cbb0-4c14-811a-4aa14d3acba1	one apparent side effect is a minor increase in a brain hormone
061e8c50-c49f-4ed6-806a-3b41d75e91af	at least two companies, cadwell laboratories inc. of kennewick, wash., and novametrix medical systems inc. of wallingford, conn., now sell versions of the magnetic devices
e5cd3eae-7a9e-4659-aacf-3bf2e172090f	the machines, which at $12,500 are inexpensive by medical standards, haven't been approved in the u.s. for marketing as brain stimulators but are sold for stimulating nerves in the hand, legs and other non-brain areas
be8fec53-8efa-4366-8bf2-d951cb948346	similarly, a purdue university team led by heart researcher w.a. tacker hopes to develop ways to magnetically induce cardiac muscle contractions

5422a791-4882-4b9d-8d07-b6cd38a173cf	they are useful to call public attention to grievances, but they have little value in educating anyone about the issues in dispute
